intro: Chionocharis hookeri, commonly known as the Hooker's snowbell, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the high-altitude regions of the Andes in South America. It is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves and clusters of small, bell-shaped white flowers that bloom in late winter or early spring. The plant thrives in cool, moist environments and is often found in rocky or alpine soils. Its unique morphology and seasonal flowering make it a distinctive species within the Campanulaceae family. Due to its specific habitat requirements, it is considered a rare and endangered plant in its natural range.
